text:
# Raynaud Differentiation and Upper-Limb Pathology Framework
## Raynaud primary vs secondary
| Feature | Primary Raynaud | Secondary Raynaud |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Typical age/pattern | younger, symmetric, no ulcers | older onset/asymmetric, digital ischemic lesions possible |
| Tissue injury | absent | ulcers/pitting scars can appear |
| Nailfold findings | usually normal | abnormal giant/tortuous capillary loops may appear |

## Core treatment
- Trigger control: warmth and smoking cessation.
- First-line pharmacology: dihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker (for example nifedipine/amlodipine).

## Transition to upper-limb block
```
Upper-limb pathology
├── Shoulder: stiffness vs weakness vs instability vs nerve entrapment
└── Elbow: tendinopathy vs bursitis (septic vs non-septic)
```
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22

text:
# Shoulder Pathology I: Adhesive Capsulitis and Rotator Cuff
## Adhesive capsulitis
- Progressive painful stiffness with both active and passive ROM limitation.
- Linked with diabetes and hypothyroidism.
- Treatment ladder: ROM-focused PT -> NSAID/injection -> selected procedural release for refractory disease.

## Rotator cuff disease
| Pattern | Key clue | Typical next step |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Tendinopathy/impingement | pain with overhead motion but near-preserved strength | PT + analgesic strategy |
| Tear (partial/full) | weakness/drop-arm pattern | MRI characterization and surgical consideration if major functional loss |

## Diagnostic pearl
- Passive ROM preserved favors cuff pathology; passive ROM restricted favors frozen shoulder.
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22

text:
# Shoulder Pathology II and Elbow Tendinopathy
## Shoulder dislocation
- Anterior dislocation (most common): abduction/external-rotation mechanism; check axillary nerve sensation pre/post reduction.
- Posterior dislocation: classically after seizure/electrocution; can be subtle on standard AP films.

## Suprascapular nerve entrapment
- Can mimic cuff weakness (abduction/external-rotation weakness) with denervation/atrophy clues.
- MRI/EMG helps distinguish nerve compression from tendon rupture.

## Lateral epicondylopathy
- Degenerative extensor tendon insertion overload rather than pure inflammatory process.
- Pain reproduced by resisted wrist extension.
- Counterforce bracing/activity modification are first-line conservative approaches.
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22

text:
# Olecranon Bursitis Decision Pathway
## Septic vs non-septic split
| Feature | Non-septic bursitis | Septic bursitis |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Trigger | repetitive pressure/trauma over time | inoculation/skin break/infection context |
| Local findings | mild swelling, less erythema/systemic signs | erythema, warmth, marked tenderness ± fever |
| Next step | conservative support | aspiration for Gram/culture + antibiotics |

## Management
- Septic: drainage/aspiration plus anti-staphylococcal coverage.
- Non-septic: padding, activity modification, anti-inflammatory support.
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22

text:
# Rapid Recap: Shoulder and Elbow + Hand/Wrist Transition
## Summary table
| Pathology | Key clue | First-line approach |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Frozen shoulder | active+passive ROM both reduced | mobilization-focused therapy |
| Rotator cuff tear | weakness/drop-arm | image and consider repair if functional deficit |
| Anterior shoulder dislocation | abducted/external-rotated injury pattern | reduction + neurovascular checks |
| Posterior shoulder dislocation | seizure/electrocution context | targeted imaging + reduction |
| Tennis elbow | pain with resisted wrist extension | counterforce brace/activity modification |
| Septic bursitis | red-hot tender bursa ± fever | aspiration + antibiotics |

## Hand/wrist block introduced
- Carpal tunnel syndrome, De Quervain tenosynovitis, Dupuytren contracture, and ganglion cysts are next core entities.
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22

text:
# Hand and Wrist Pathology Framework + CTS
## Structural map
```
Hand/wrist disorders
├── Nerve compression: carpal tunnel syndrome
├── Tendon sheath disorder: De Quervain
├── Fascial fibrosis: Dupuytren contracture
└── Benign cystic lesion: ganglion cyst
```

## Carpal tunnel syndrome
- Median-nerve distribution paresthesia (thumb/index/middle/radial ring); pinky sparing helps localization.
- Night symptoms with shaking-hand relief are classic.
- Common associated contexts: pregnancy, diabetes, hypothyroidism, dialysis/amyloid states, RA.

## Evaluation and treatment
| Stage | Approach |
| --- | --- |
| Mild/moderate | night splint +/- local steroid strategy |
| Persistent/progressive | electrodiagnostics in uncertain cases and decompression surgery |
| Motor deficit/thenar atrophy | urgent decompression consideration |
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22

text:
# CTS Progression, De Quervain, and Dupuytren
## Severe CTS clues
- Thenar atrophy and thumb opposition/abduction weakness indicate chronic axonal compromise.

## De Quervain tenosynovitis
- Radial wrist pain from APL/EPB first dorsal compartment overuse.
- Finkelstein maneuver reproduces pain.
- Treatment: thumb-spica immobilization, anti-inflammatory care, injection if persistent.

## Dupuytren contracture
- Palmar fascial fibrosis causing flexion contracture (often ring/little fingers).
- Table-top test identifies functional extension limitation.
- Management spectrum: observation -> needle/collagenase interventions -> fasciectomy for disabling contracture.
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22

text:
# Dupuytren Continuation and Ganglion Cyst
## Dupuytren details
- Nodules/cords reflect fascia pathology (not primary tendon disease).
- Recurrence remains possible after procedures.

## Ganglion cyst
- Dorsal wrist mass with gelatinous fluid from joint capsule/tendon sheath outpouching.
- Transillumination may support cystic nature.

## Management table
| Clinical context | Preferred strategy |
| --- | --- |
| Asymptomatic ganglion | reassurance/observation |
| Symptomatic or cosmetic concern | aspiration (higher recurrence) or excision for definitive control |

## Practical pearl
- Historical “bible-bump” trauma approach is not recommended modern care.
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22

text:
# Rapid Recap: Hand/Wrist and Spine Transition
## Hand/wrist Q&A summary
| Prompt | High-yield answer |
| --- | --- |
| De Quervain tendons | APL + EPB |
| Typical CTS splint | night wrist splint (neutral) |
| De Quervain splint | thumb-spica |
| Ganglion bedside clue | positive transillumination |
| Common Dupuytren digits | ring and little fingers |
| Asymptomatic ganglion management | observe/reassure |

## Transition to spine
- Next block: cervical/lumbar radiculopathy, stenosis, myelopathy, trauma clearance, and red-flag emergencies.
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22

text:
# Spine Pathology Framework and Cervical Radiculopathy
## Top-down classification
```
Spine pathology
├── Cervical
│   ├── Radiculopathy (nerve-root pattern)
│   └── Myelopathy (cord dysfunction, higher urgency)
├── Lumbar
│   ├── Disc/radiculopathy (sciatic pattern)
│   ├── Stenosis (neurogenic claudication)
│   └── Spondylolisthesis/spondylolysis
└── Trauma and red-flag emergencies
```

## Three bedside archetypes
| Archetype | Typical pattern | Likely syndrome |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Shooter | dermatomal electric radiating pain | radiculopathy |
| Leaner | better when flexed/leaning forward | lumbar stenosis |
| Stumbler | gait clumsiness/fine-motor decline | myelopathy |

## Cervical radiculopathy pearls
- Spurling provocation can reproduce root pain.
- Shoulder-abduction relief sign supports cervical root compression pattern.
- Root-level deficits map by reflex/motor/sensory pattern for localization.
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22

text:
# Cervical Myelopathy and Lumbar Disorders
## Cervical myelopathy (urgent)
- Cord compression pattern: hand clumsiness, gait instability, UMN signs (hyperreflexia/Babinski/Hoffmann).
- MRI cervical spine is key diagnostic step.
- Surgical decompression is definitive treatment for progressive/significant disease.

## Low-back imaging rule
- Without red flags and severe/progressive deficits, initial acute low-back pain is managed conservatively without immediate MRI.

## Lumbar stenosis vs vascular claudication
| Feature | Neurogenic stenosis | Vascular claudication |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Aggravation | standing/extension | exertion workload |
| Relief | flexion/sitting | rest regardless posture |
| Pulses/trophic changes | usually preserved | often reduced with PAD signs |

## Lumbar radiculopathy highlights
- L5: dorsiflexion weakness/foot drop tendency.
- S1: plantar-flexion weakness and reduced Achilles reflex.
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22

text:
# Lumbar Red Flags, Trauma Protocols, and NEXUS
## Spondylolysis/spondylolisthesis
- Extension-heavy sports can produce pars defects and vertebral slippage.
- Palpable step-off may be present in more advanced cases.

## Critical red flags
| Emergency | Key clue | Action |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Cauda equina syndrome | saddle anesthesia + bladder/bowel dysfunction | emergent MRI + urgent decompression |
| Epidural infection/tumor concern | fever/immunosuppression or cancer pattern with neuro deficits | urgent MRI and specialist pathway |

## Additional pediatric pearl
- Vertebra plana in child raises concern for Langerhans-cell spectrum pathology.

## Trauma clearance
- Initial spinal immobilization until clearance.
- NEXUS-based screening guides who requires CT imaging.
- If one significant spinal fracture is found, broader spine imaging assessment is typically required.
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22

text:
# Rapid Recap: Spine High-Yield Exam Patterns
| Scenario | Most likely diagnosis | Next step |
| --- | --- | --- |
| hand on head relieves arm radicular pain | cervical radiculopathy | focused neuro exam +/- targeted imaging if persistent/progressive |
| hand clumsiness + gait imbalance + UMN signs | cervical myelopathy | urgent cervical MRI and decompression pathway |
| relief when leaning over shopping cart | lumbar spinal stenosis | conservative care then decompression if refractory |
| foot-drop pattern | L5 radiculopathy | neurologic localization and escalation if deficit progresses |
| loss of tip-toe power + low Achilles reflex | S1 radiculopathy | root-level management strategy |
| saddle anesthesia + urinary retention/incontinence | cauda equina syndrome | emergent MRI + surgery |
| acute low-back pain without red flags | nonspecific mechanical lumbago | NSAID/activity continuation, no immediate MRI |
| pediatric vertebra plana | possible Langerhans histiocytic lesion | pediatric oncology/ortho workup |

## Cleanup
- Removed quiz invitations/non-learning caveat language; retained exam-critical decision rules.
subject: LM_OSRHM 30046f2986ee8098921dc4e04b63ee22
